A former Russian military tank commander convicted of leading a Taliban attack on U.S. forces in Afghanistan is set to be sentenced today in Richmond, Virginia.

The case was unique from others that have been tried in the U.S. involving terror suspects because Irek Hamidullin was a combatant captured on the battlefield and not a financier, recruiter or schemer arrested outside the theater of war.
link_name: Russian convicted in attack on U.S. forces to be sentenced

link_name: Afghan Taliban ambush helicopter after emergency landing; 3 die

PT365 | Shadow runs let service members participate in big stateside races while deployed. The idea is as much about connecting troops to those back home as it is racing in the sandbox.

"I know first-hand how meaningful it is for deployed servicemen to feel like they are a part of something greater such as this shadow run — especially when it's an event in honor of them," says retired Army Brig. Gen. Jack Hammond, now director of the Home Base Program.
link_name: Race from afar: Shadow runs let deployed service members participate in stateside races | PT365

link_name: Paxton: Lack of ships hurt typhoon relief mission in Philippines

status_message:
IN CASE YOU MISSED IT: Staff Sgt. Richard Faulkner was the only surviving crew member when his bomber was shot down on a mission to Augsburg, Germany, on March 18, 1944. He spent a month eluding the Nazis in occupied France and later declined a Purple Heart because he did not feel it was right to accept the decoration after all his buddies perished. Late last month, at age 89, Faulkner finally received his Purple Heart because he wants to pass it down to his grandchildren.

Help us share this man's story of service and sacrifice:
link_name: After 70 years, WWII gunner finally accepts Purple Heart

status_message: BREAKING TONIGHT: Defense officials have ordered a review of options that include consolidating commissaries and exchanges, as well as having commissaries adopt an "Exchange-like business model," according to information obtained by Military Times. Officials also intend to ask Congress for two "significant changes" in law: allowing commissaries to raise prices rather than sell groceries at cost from distributors and manufacturers; and allowing commissaries to sell generic products, rather than limiting the stores to selling name-brand goods. Complete details here:
link_name: DoD to look at consolidating commissaries, exchanges

status_message:
Our thoughts are with the family of Marine Maj. Kurt Chew-een Lee, a legendary hero at Chosin Reservoir during the Korean War, who died Monday at his home in Washington, D.C. He was 88.

Lee earned the Navy Cross and the Silver Star for separate acts of valor within a one-month period during the early part of the war. He was also the Corps' first Asian American regular officer.
link_name: Maj. Kurt Lee, Korean War hero, dies at 88

status_message:
Could this shirt lower your core temperature and raise your summer PT performance?

In a study that wrapped up a few months ago, Dr. Reggie O'Hara, an exercise physiologist with the 711th Human Performance Wing, and his research team found that the cooling shirt not only significantly reduced core body temperature in 12 fit military volunteers during 70-minute workouts, it also reduced blood lactate levels.

Get the details from OFFduty writer Jon Anderson, here:
link_name: New cool thing in sportswear? Air Force lab is developing the refrigerator of T-shirts | PT365

status_message: THE LATEST ON UKRAINE-RUSSIA TENSION: A retired U.S. general with deep knowledge of the geopolitical dynamics at play in Ukraine says the country's military will stand its ground if Russian forces launch an assault. The Russian army relies heavily on tanks, but the Ukrainian military's ability to counter Russian armor is limited. Its forces have old T-72 tanks, BMP-1 fighting vehicles and third-generation anti-tank missiles. Even still, the general says, if the Ukrainians are attacked, "they are going to fight." More here:
link_name: Retired U.S. general touts Ukrainian troops' toughness

status_message: TODAY'S TOP TALKER: Maj. Jess Mullen, a 37-year-old mother of four, says all Marines can do pullups if they put their mind to it and train effectively. Meanwhile, the Marine Corps needs to make adjustments to its methodology for gathering data, she writes. Her letter to the editor appeared in the Feb. 24 issue of Marine Corps Times. Read it here:
link_name: One officer's opinion: Marines who can't do pullups are 'broke or lazy'

status_message: Our thoughts tonight are with the family and friends of retired Air Force Col. George Robert Hall, who died Sunday after a 20-year battle with Parkinson's Disease. A Vietnam War veteran, Hall endured nearly eight years as a prisoner of war, one of the longest periods of captivity in American history. Rest in peace, Sir.
link_name: Vietnam veteran, POW George Robert Hall dies at 83

status_message:
Several readers have reached out to us about some photos shared on social media that showed a group of soldiers — some grinning, some striking comic poses — beside a casket draped in the American flag. One was captioned, "We put the FUN in funeral your fearless honor guard from various states." 

Our colleagues at Army Times have reported that the Wisconsin National Guard has suspended a soldier from a funeral honors detail over the photos. Full details here:
link_name: Soldier suspended in funeral guard photo flap; investigation launched

status_message: Photo blog: A Marine awaits the arrival of President Obama in drought stricken California

status_message: Our thoughts today are with the family and friends of Master Sgt. Aaron Torian, 2nd Marine Special Operations Battalion, who died Saturday in Afghanistan.

status_message: NEW TODAY: Marine Corps Commandant Gen. Jim Amos ordered Marine Corps Times be returned to its prominent newsstand location in exchange stores amid growing media attention to its sudden move to an area where it was less visible, a team of public affairs officers said during an interview late last week. The interview was conducted in the wake of growing attention to whether the independent newspaper was moved from checkout areas to the back of the store because of sometimes critical coverage of Amos and senior leadership. A spokesman said the commandant "recognized how this would be perceived" and ordered the newspaper moved back pending a thorough study. Read more here:
link_name: Marine Corps explains why it abruptly relocated independent newspaper

status_message: NEW TONIGHT: A senior Marine officer who was fined $18,000 and formally reprimanded after being convicted at court-martial late last year of fraternizing with a senior enlisted Marine is protesting her treatment, saying she was falsely accused by someone with a grudge. Read the full story here:
link_name: Trailblazing Marine officer faces sour end to her career

status_message: NEW TONIGHT: A picture showing a woman wearing an Air Force uniform tongue-kissing a Prisoner of War-Missing in Action symbol has gone viral, infuriating bloggers and veterans. Marine Corps veteran Michael Kelley felt "blind fury and disgust" when he saw the picture, he said Friday in an interview. "It goes completely against everything that we're taught in the military from Day 1," Kelley said. "She failed herself; she's failed the Air Force and the military community as a whole by doing something that disrespectful and then having it get out to the world like that." Read more:
link_name: Photo of airman kissing POW-MIA symbol causes uproar

status_message:
If you're active-duty and planning on registering for the Marine Corps Marathon, listen up:

General registration for this year's Marine Corps Marathon will be through a lottery, but active-duty and reservist runners will still register during a first-come, first-served window starting Feb. 19.

Once those slots are filled, military runners will have to registration through the public lottery.
link_name: Marine Corps Marathon priority registration opens Feb. 19 with 15% discount, limited bibs | PT365

status_message: LEADING TODAY: A newly-released email shows that 11 days after the killing of Osama bin Laden in 2011, the U.S. military's top special operations officer ordered subordinates to destroy any photographs of the al-Qaida founder's corpse or turn them over to the CIA. Read more here:
link_name: SOCOM chief's email shows effort to shield bin Laden photos

status_message: BREAKING TONIGHT: Four Marines will be recognized next week for their heroism during a 2012 operation in Afghanistan. First Lt. Kenneth Conover III and Sgt. Kenneth Rick will each receive a Silver Star while Staff Sgt. Joshua Brodrick and Sgt. Nicholas Brandau will each receive a Bronze Star with combat "V" device. All are members of 1st Battalion, 7th Marines, in Twentynine Palms, Calif. Salute!
link_name: Twentynine Palms Marines to receive Silver and Bronze stars for six-day battle in 2012

status_message:
Fallen Cpl. Jason Dunham, who is one of two Marines to receive the Medal of Honor for heroic actions in Iraq or Afghanistan, will have a new building named for him aboard Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center Twentynine Palms, Calif. 

Cpl. Jason L. Dunham Hall will be dedicated next Tuesday.
link_name: Marine Corps names building for MOH recipient Cpl. Jason Dunham

status_message:
NEW TODAY: A female Marine brig guard has been charged after a male inmate claimed he was sexually assaulted and harassed by staff at Naval Consolidated Brig Miramar. 
Lance Cpl. Lacey Kohlman, a former brig guard, is charged with dereliction of duty, false official statements, and violation of a federal statute. 
Inmate Shane Bardes, an infantry Marine convicted of rape, claims Kohlman and other brig staff had sexual encounters with him, groped him without permission, and humiliated him.
link_name: Charges filed against female guard linked to Miramar brig scandal

status_message:
Many runners believe that to be better runners, they need to run more, run longer, run faster — and that strength training will only make them tight, sap their flexibility and raise their risk of pulled muscles and injuries.

Not true, writes Military Muscle columnist Bob Thomas. Strength training improves your running, lowering the risk of injury, both running- and nonrunning-related.

Read his strength training for runners workout, here:
link_name: Military Muscle: 4 strength drills to improve your running speed | PT365

U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. Samantha Power said today that officials can't jump from doing nothing in #Syria to deploying #Marines. 

"President Obama has instructed all of us to ... look at every tool that we have in the toolbox and see what we can deploy so that we don't confront a choice between doing nothing on the one hand and sending in the Marines on the other," Power told NPR.

status_message: NEW TODAY: Pentagon proposals to reportedly slice $1 billion from the annual commissary budget may not hinge on closing stores, but on raising prices for patrons, sources said. Options under consideration include raising the 5 percent surcharge that customers pay at the register, increasing prices on individual goods in the stores or both. Advocates say it could signal the death knell for commissaries. Read more here:
link_name: Stores won't close, but prices may increase

status_message:
Col. Michael Colburn, director of the #Marine Band, is retiring from the Corps this year. When asked what it was like to carry out his career on a stage, he said he always remember who the band represents. 

"It's especially during our tour concerts when we play the 'Armed Forces Medley' ... that we remember all the men and women serving in uniform who are in difficult and trying circumstances where no one is offering applause," Colburn told Marine Corps Times. "In those moments, we feel we are representing all those troops when performing for the American public."
link_name: 'Presidents Own' leader looks back on time with elite Marine band

status_message: BREAKING: Last year's deadly training accident at Hawthorne Army Depot in Nevada, which left seven Marines dead and cost three officers their jobs, was the result of a double-loaded mortar round, a newly released investigation concludes. Full details here:

status_message:
New Today: The Marine Corps is tightening its travel and expense policies in response to an embezzlement scandal involving reservists that hit headlines late last year.
Lt. Gen. Richard Mills, commander of Marine Forces Reserve, said in an interview that the Marine Corps is eliminating cash advances for travel and increasing oversight on temporary active duty orders to discourage dishonesty and theft.
link_name: Embezzlement ring scandal leads to Marine Corps policy changes

NEW TODAY: #Marines with the Black Sea Rotational Force are training in #Finland for the first time.

They'll be working with Finnish soldiers, swapping skills on arctic and urban warfare, in areas that average single-digit temperatures in January. They'll gather food, stay overnight in snow caves and practice skiing techniques in the frigid temperatures.

status_message:
Members of 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing now have a new obstacle course aboard Marine Corps Air Station Miramar, Calif., thanks to the idea of two noncommissioned officers. 

Sgts. Mark Willoughby Jr. and Mark Sanchez had the idea for an o-course aboard the air station. Willoughby asked Maj. Gen. Steven Busby, their commanding general, why they didn't have one during a leadership breakfast at the CG's home. Busby listened, and the base opened their new course this week.  

A section of the course is named Willoughby's Wall, for the young NCO who had the courage to speak up to his CG about something he saw lacking.
link_name: – 3rd MAW opens obstacle course after corporal asks for one

status_message:
New Today: the three-star head of Marine Forces Reserve, Lt. Gen. Richard Mills, says budgetary woes will hit home for all Marines, but the impact on the reserves will be intensified.

Fewer reservists may travel to large-scale training exercises, such as Bold Alligator off the Carolina coast; equipment might be sidelined because the reserves are unable to maintain it; and reserve unit commanders could be forced to cut out visits to their units, all on account of fiscal austerity. Mills said officials are already examining ways to restructure training and reexamine equipment use so they can make the best of reserve time and resources.
link_name: Mills: 2014 critical year for Reserves

status_message: LEADING TODAY: Celebrated military author Bing West took the stand Wednesday to defend Maj. Jason Brezler, a decorated officer facing punitive actions that could end his career, saying he would trust Brezler with "my life, my savings, and my family." West was among a high-profile lineup of witnesses who spoke in defense of Brezler, who is accused of substandard conduct for bringing 107 classified documents back from the war zone on a personal hard drive and, several years later, sending one of them over an insecure network to a Marine colleague in Afghanistan.

status_message: NEW TONIGHT ON MARINE CORPS TIMES PRIME: Marine personnel officials say staff sergeants may no longer be guaranteed a 20-year career and full retirement benefits if a new policy is approved for fiscal 2014. The plan calls for all staff sergeants with between 15 and 18 years of service and who have been twice passed over for promotion to go before a retention board and potentially face an early retirement. link_name: Marine Corps: Guaranteed careers for staff sergeants at risk

status_message:
"Marines don't do that." 
 
That's the simple phrase a Harvard professor thinks #Marines can say in order to stop each other from behaving badly. If one person in the unit observing negative behavior steps forward to say, "Marines don't do that," it reminds them of who they are, and lets them know their brothers are with them, he said.

Can it work? Tell us what you think. Share your comments below or on Battle Rattle.
link_name: Professor: Marines can stop bad behavior by speaking up, reminding wrong-doers of their identity

status_message: NEW TODAY: Appearing before Britain's Parliament, a British three-star disputed assertions his forces are to blame for the security failures that led to last year's Taliban attack on a coalition airfield in which two Marines were killed. Lt. Gen. David Capewell said that even though the Brits were in charge of security for Camp Bastion, they are not responsible for the incident. Two Marine generals were asked to retire as a result while those in charge of Bastion have been promoted. More on our Battle Rattle blog:
link_name: UK media: British 3-star disputes claim his troops failed to prevent Camp Bastion attack

status_message: NEW TONIGHT: Military personnel who are medically retired — those with combat or service-related injuries so severe they were offered full military retirement pay and benefits — would see their retired pay cut as a result of the 2013 Bipartisan Budget Act, a U.S. senator said Tuesday. Details here:
link_name: Medical retirees included in COLA reductions

status_message: BREAKING: Congressional negotiators have decided on a 1 percent military pay raise for 2014 but are taking steps to ensure the White House is responsible for what would be the smallest annual pay bump since the birth of the all-volunteer force 40 years ago. The 1 percent raise, which would be effective Jan. 1, also would end a string of 21 consecutive years in which the military pay raise matched or exceeded private-sector wage growth. Full details:
link_name: 1% pay raise for 2014 appears likely

status_message:
NEW TODAY: There is a reason that Marines seeking tuition assistance at their base education center are being deferred.

The money for the first quarter is gone.

Rather than having $11 million to spend on tuition aid in October, November and December, the Corps actually had only $3.5 million, and that money went quickly — distributed among installations based on historical use over the past three fiscal years. It is unclear how much money will be available in the second quarter, but it may be the same amount.
link_name: Tuition assistance funds gone; outlook unclear

link_name: Marine officer to receive Silver Star for heroics in Camp Bastion attack

status_message: NEW TODAY: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has enacted plans to reduce DOD staff by 20 percent, an effort he said will save the Pentagon $1 billion over five years. The changes involve eliminating civilian and contract workers, while reorganizing the oversight responsibilities of some of DoD's senior officials. Plans also call for an overhaul of the policy directorate, including the elimination of one deputy undersecretary and four deputy assistant secretaries.
link_name: DoD begins cutting staff sizes, will reorganize policy office

status_message: NEW TONIGHT: The commander of Marine Forces Reserve has found that his own actions regarding a Marine officer's high-profile legal proceedings do not constitute a conflict of interest and do not require him to recuse himself as convening authority in the case. Lt. Gen. Richard Mills denied a motion in the case of Maj. Jason Brezler that requested Mills be replaced because of emails he sent to other general officers regarding the case. Brezler's attorney alleged Mills tried to discourage a one-star from writing a letter in support of his client. Full details:
link_name: General denies conflict of interest motion in Brezler case

status_message: BREAKING: DOD will close its walk-in Tricare Service Centers in the U.S., a money-saving move that is part of the reorganization of the military medical system. Officials said Thursday that the centers, which provide beneficiaries with face-to-face assistance on claims paperwork, enrollment changes, processing and more, were inefficient and underutilized. Customers can be better served with a toll-free telephone customer service center or online, they concluded. Details here:
link_name: DoD to close domestic Tricare Service Centers

status_message: NEW TODAY ON MARINE CORPS TIMES PRIME: The Corps' has deactivated its tactical air operations center in southwestern Afghanistan, handing off the mission to the Air Force and marking the end of a significant operation. Since 2009, Marines at the TAOC coordinated more than 400,000 fixed-wing and rotary flights in support of coalition forces throughout Afghanistan. Details:
link_name: Marines close air operations center in Afghanistan, hand off mission to Air Force

status_message: NEW TODAY: Sharp analysis from our congressional editor on lawmakers attempt to reach a deal on the $3.5 trillion federal budget for 2014. The House and Senate are only $90 billion apart, but closing that gap is proving difficult because nobody is budging. What's your read? Will Congress find a compromise by Jan. 15 to avoid another shutdown and prevent $109 billion in sequestration cuts that would lop $53 billion from the defense budget?
link_name: Clock ticking on budget deal; defense spending still unresolved

status_message: TODAY'S BIG STORY: A combat-wounded Marine accused of defrauding the government as part of an embezzlement scheme was acquitted this month after defense attorneys argued during his court-martial that his command took extraordinary measures to ensure he was punished. The case against Staff Sgt. Anthony Rios Jr. is significant because his legal team tied the aggressive effort to prosecute him to the commandant's Heritage Brief presentation delivered last year throughout the Corps. Details:
link_name: Marine cleared in fraud case after lawyers cite influence of commandant's Heritage Brief

status_message:
A British Royal Marine was found guilty of murdering an insurgent during a court-martial in England on Friday. The Royal Marine was accused of shooting a man in the chest at close-range after he was injured in a helicopter attack during a Sept. 2011 deployment to Afghanistan. 

"Obviously, this doesn't go anywhere, fellas," he could be heard saying after he shot the man. "I've just broke the Geneva Convention."

The Royal Marine now faces life in prison.
link_name: – Royal Marine found guilty of murder based on warzone helmet camera footage

status_message: IN CASE YOU MISSED IT: Meet the Rossiters, a Marine family bonded by a child's terminal illness. Maj. Kim Rossiter's 9-year-old daughter Ainsley has a rare genetic nerve disorder, but they've refused to let that keep her on the sidelines. Together, Ainsely and her dad have completed 57 races — including last month's Marine Corps Marathon — with him on foot pushing her in a running chair. Simply put, this may be the most touching story you'll see all year. Watch the video here: http://bit.ly/1blo9ak

Kim "Rooster" Rossiter's 9-year-old daughter Ainsley has a rare genetic nerve disorder, but they've refused to let that keep her on the sidelines. Together, Ainsely and her dad have completed 57 races — including last month's Marine Corps Marathon — with him on foot pushing her in a running chair. Simply put, this may be the most touching story you'll see all year. Watch it here: http://bit.ly/1blo9ak

The Corps' tests on common uniform items for male and female Marines stemmed from the Navy secretary's philosophy that all service members should look the same — regardless of gender.

Navy Secretary Ray Mabus said when he looks at a group of Marines, he shouldn't see female and male Marines, just Marines.

"That's the advantage of having one cover," he said.
link_name: SecNav's ideas on uniformity are behind unisex wear-tests

status_message: NEW TONIGHT: The long-term budget cuts known as sequestration — intended to shrink spending and reduce debt — are actually costing the Corps billions of wasted dollars due to inefficiency, Gen. Jim Amos told Congress on Thursday. The service cannot sign new multi-year contracts and is being forced to cancel current ones, paying a penalty for doing so, he said. "In Marine aviation alone, it's going to cost me $6.5 billion of inefficiences," he said. "That's four [F-35B Joint Strike Fighter] squadrons and two MV-22 Osprey squadrons." Full details:
link_name: Amos: Sequestration is costing the Marine Corps billions

status_message: NEW TONIGHT: In a new essay appearing in the U.S. Naval Institute's Proceedings magazine, the commandant says a force of 174,000 Marines — but no fewer — balances ongoing operational requirements with crisis-response capabilities, although it assumes increased risk in the event of war. Its publication comes days before Gen. Jim Amos and the other service chiefs are due to testify before the Senate Armed Services Committee regarding planning and the impacts of the long-term budget cuts known as sequestration. Full details:
link_name: Amos defends Marine Corps force of 174,000

status_message: NEW TODAY: A panel of experts told the new commission studying potential changes to the military compensation and retirement system that a top priority should be shifting some long-term and non-cash benefits into more simple and immediate cash payments for troops. Non-monetary compensation, such as lifelong health care options and a generous retirement plan, may not be the most effective way to recruit, pay and retain troops and sustain the all-volunteer force, they contend. Full details here:
link_name: Compensation experts: Give troops more cash, reduce in-kind benefits

status_message:
ON THE COVER: What cutting the force to 174K or below would mean.

The Marine Corps' personnel drawdown plan for the year ahead has taken shape, but a lingering threat of steeper cuts leaves open the possibility that these carefully laid efforts could be upended.

At present, the Corps is on pace to whittle its active-duty force to 174,000 Marines by the end of 2017, eliminating approximately 5,000 positions a year and relying heavily on voluntary, incentive-based measures to get there. But there's a fat, ugly elephant in the room: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel's bleak predication in August that the spending caps known as sequestration could drive Marine end strength as low as 150,000.
link_name: Cutting to 174K or below: What happens if the Corps accelerates its drawdown

Lance corporals will soon participate in a new seminar as part of their professional military education. The idea is to give them some face-to-face time with unit leadership to talk about issues like ethics, sexual assault prevention and hazing.

"A lot of Marines feel like they're left out at times," said Gunnery Sgt. Edwin Hidalgo, who started a lance corporals seminar in his unit. "Now we're going back and saying, 'You are important.'"

status_message: NEW TODAY: DOD has changed its disability policy to include chronic adjustment disorder as a condition potentially eligible for disability pay. Thousands have been discharged for the disorder, which was characterized as a condition present before troops joined the military, and therefore ineligible for compensation or mental health treatment. Critics have said the military used such diagnoses in lieu of post-traumatic stress disorder to avoid paying those who can no longer serve.
link_name: Adjustment disorder may now net disability pay

status_message:
NEW TODAY: Four women attempted the Infantry Officer Course at Quantico, Va., beginning yesterday, and none made it through the initial Combat Endurance Test. 

Ten women have now attempted IOC since last year as part of the Marine Corps' ongoing research into which combat jobs should be opened to women. Nine failed the initial CET, while the tenth made it through last fall but had withdraw from IOC afterward due to injury.

On the enlisted side, meanwhile, 13 of the 15 women who reported to Camp Geiger, N.C., last week to take the Infantry Training Battalion course are still in training. They are the first women to attempt enlisted infantry training in the Corps.
link_name: 4 more female Marines fall short at Infantry Officer Course

status_message:
"We have never met. We have never spoken. But I would like to believe that I know something about each of you through the actions of your loved ones on that day. They were a part of a Team. And you are now a part of that Team. I would be honored for you to attend a ceremony that will acknowledge what that team represented.

"The ceremony will be October 15th and 16th, respectively at the White House and Pentagon. If you wish to attend, please contact me and I will provide whatever information I can. I sincerely look forward to meeting you."

-- Army Capt. Will Swenson
link_name: – Next Medal of Honor recipient sends touching invitation to Gold Star families

status_message:
BREAKING TONIGHT: Medal of Honor recipient Dakota Meyer tells Marine Corps Times he does indeed have interest in running for Congress, but he left the time frame unclear.

"I love Americans and I believe in this country," he said. "I really appreciate the overwhelming support and encouragement, and I hope to someday serve America again."

Meyer spoke to Marine Corps Times after he raised the prospect of a congressional run early Tuesday on Twitter.

"Congress 2016, POTUS 2024!" he said.

status_message: By a 420-0 vote, the House passed a measure promising military members, some federal civilians and some federal contractors will be paid even if funds for other government operations expire. Passage of the military pay protection bill shows "we are getting closer and closer to a shutdown," said Rep. Frank Pallone, D-N.Y.
link_name: House votes to protect military pay as shutdown looks more likely

status_message:
The Marine Corps has removed from his job a staff judge advocate who publicly accused Commandant Gen. Jim Amos of unlawful command influence in the high-profile cases against eight Marines prosecuted in connection with a war-zone video of scout snipers urinating on enemy corpses.

Maj. James Weirick was also placed under a  Marine Corps Protective Order and asked to turn in his personal weapons and submit to a voluntary psychiatric evaluation.
link_name: Marine Corps whistleblower relieved following allegations of email harrassment

status_message:
Our breaking story posted last night about Commandant Gen. Jim Amos' call for tough new restrictions on barracks life has been updated with a statement from him.

Said Gen. Amos:

"It is impossible to overstate my pride in the brilliant performance of our Marines through 12 years of sustained combat. As the Corps resets itself for the conflicts and crises to come, the magnificence of the many has thrown into sharp relief the failure of the few to live up to our high standards. Rather than wait for a creeping complacency to set in, I'm turning to my leaders at all levels to refocus Marines on what we do and who we are."
link_name: Commandant calls for new crackdown on barracks life, Marine behavior

status_message:
BREAKING TONIGHT: Commandant Gen. Jim Amos told his general officers this week that he wants tough new measures put in place in barracks across the service to 'reawaken' Marines morally and crack down on bad behavior, Marine Corps Times has learned.

 The commandant's plan calls for a variety of new initiatives, including the installation of security cameras in each barracks, the incorporation of more staff noncommissioned officers and officers on duty, and the arming of all Marines on duty at all times, according to briefing slides from the commandant's address.

Marine Corps Times will continue to develop this story. If you have an opinion or more information, email senior writer Dan Lamothe at dlamothe (at) marinecorpstimes.com.
link_name: Commandant calls for new crackdown on barracks life, Marine behavior

status_message:
NEW TODAY: Fifteen women reported yesterday to enlisted infantry training overseen by the School of Infantry at Camp Geiger, N.C. It is part of the Marine Corps' ongoing assessment of which jobs in the service should be open to women, following the repeal last year of the Pentagon's policy excluding women from direct combat assignments.

Marine officials said Wednesday that the women will begin training alongside their male peers, and eventually move into the "0311" infantry riflemen program of instruction. They will not be awarded the 0311 military occupational specialty.
link_name: 15 female Marines report for enlisted infantry training

Rep. Dan Kildee, D-Mich., launched a social media media campaign called #FreeAmir to draw awareness to Amir Hekmati's case. Hekmati is a former Marine sergeant who has been held in an Iranian prison for two years.

status_message: The Corps is in the process of boosting the number of Marine Security Guards by 1,000, nearly doubling the size of the force. status_message:
Our hats are off to the Marines who repelled the attack this year on Forward Operating Base Shir Ghazay in Afghanistan. Here's the recollection of Lance Cpl. Joel Murray, one of those involved:

"I saw Corporal McSweeney drawing his rifle up, and I saw the insurgents coming through the breach. From there, we engaged them. Once we realized that they were down and we were clear to move up, McSweeney and myself moved up to the first casualty that we saw, which was a Georgian soldier. He had a leg injury. As I applied the tourniquet, Corporal McSweeney was providing cover for me because we were about 15 yards from the actual blast site."
link_name: The inside story: How hero logisticians helped shut down a Taliban breach

status_message: A strike on Syria would involve launches of missiles solely from ships, according to the two senior officers familiar with the planning. The Air Force can fire missiles from outside Syrian air space but are not expected to take part in the mission, the officers said.

status_message:
The investigation into the relief of Lt. Col. Ned Biehl, former commanding officer of Marine Medium Helicopter Squadron 364, shows that he brought four bottles of liquor onto a ship without authorization. Biehl, who was relieved of command in March, was deployed with the 15th Marine Expeditionary Unit at the time.

In a statement provided to Marine Corps Times, Biehl commended the service of the Marines and sailors he led.
 
"...One event does not define a career of loyal and dedicated service," he added. "I remain humble and confident in all that I do and it continues to be an honor and privilege to serve my country."
link_name: Investigation: Relieved squadron CO brought alcohol onto ship

Former Sgt. Steven Rhodes was granted immediate eligibility to play NCAA football. He had been told previously that his participation in a military-only recreational football league in 2012 would hinder his immediate eligibility for Division I football.

"This has all been crazy, but I feel like I got a whole new life now," Rhodes said. "Thank the Lord, I'm going to play football this year."

Today we remember Sgt. Michael Guillory, who died in Afghanistan on Dec. 14 while serving with MARSOC-Always Faithful-Always Forward. Documents released to Marine Corps Times by U.S. Central Command say he sustained a fatal head injury during a resupply mission after his ATV fell into an eight-foot deep pit.

Guillory's mother, Gina, tells Marine Corps Times that her son's MARSOC team members have been kind to her since returning from their deployment this summer.

"His MARSOC team has been amazing," she said. "They've been really, really good to me."
link_name: MARSOC sergeant killed in Afghanistan ATV accident, investigation says

status_message:
In case you missed it, this week's Marine Corps Times cover story profiles Maj. James Weirick, the whistle-blower who filed an inspector general complaint drawing attention to the way the Marine Corps' top officers have handled legal cases connected to a viral video showing Marines urinating on dead insurgents in Afghanistan.

Weirick says in a statement to Marine Corps Times that because of an ethics allegation lodged against him by Marine Corps headquarters after he filed the IG complaint, he is unable to comment "on the facts or any other aspect" of the remaining urination video case.

"I can, however, say that Marines are expected to act in a manner befitting the title we have earned, which includes acting in an ethical manner at all times," Weirick states. "These Marines, despite what they were accused of, fought and nearly died in defense of the Constitution. I could not allow these Marines to be deprived of rights they are guaranteed by the document they swore to defend."
link_name: Whistle-blower alleges reprisal by Marine brass, says he won't back down

status_message:
The Navy has named an explosive ordnance disposal facility in Indian Head, Md., after a Marine who died in Marjah, Afghanistan in June 2010. Lance Cpl. Terry Honeycutt Jr. grew up in nearby Waldorf, Md.

Said Lt. Col. Jim Fullwood, who led Honeycutt's unit -- 2nd Battalion, 9th Marines, out of Camp Lejeune, N.C. -- in combat:

"When T.J. deployed to Afghanistan in June 2010, our battalion was sent to northern Marjah, which at the time was the most hostile area of Afghanistan. It had been a base of operations for the Taliban for many years prior. T.J.'s company was placed in the roughest part. Until the day T.J. was killed in action, he carried out hundreds of patrols and fought daily battles. That's what Marines do."
link_name: – Navy EOD building dedicated to Marine killed in Afghanistan

status_message:
President Obama highlighted the sacrifice of this Marine couple on Wednesday during his speech at Camp Pendleton, Calif. Capt. Matthew Lampert lost both legs while serving with Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command in Afghanistan, the president said. His wife, Capt. Camille Lampert, is training to become a test pilot.

"There are stories like Matt and Camille's throughout our Marine Corps," the president said. "They represent what's best in our Marine Corps. 'Semper Fidelis.' That's the ethic of your lives: Always faithful."
link_name: – Obama highlights sacrifice, heroism of Marine couple at Camp Pendleton

Staff Sgt. Ryan Culberson, a Marine who married into a "Real Housewives of Orange County" family, is making entertainment headlines for his appearance on last night's season finale. Culberson threatened to throw a woman out of his mother-in-law's home after she took her shoes off and put her feet on the couch. 

"I don't care whose mom she is," Culberson said. "You don't disrespect people's furniture and people's houses by putting your feet up on their couch."

status_message:
NEW TODAY: Our latest investigative story in ongoing coverage of how top Marine Corps officers have handled legal cases for personnel facing charges related to the viral video showing scout snipers urinating on Taliban corpses in Afghanistan. Please read it and consider sharing it if you have been tracking the issue.

____________________________

The Marine Corps commandant's controversial handling of legal cases tied to the infamous video of scout snipers urinating on Taliban corpses has caught the eye of attorneys involved in another hot-button issue for the military: sexual assault.

Mounting evidence that Gen. Jim Amos and some of his top legal advisers may have deliberately sought to sway the outcome of the war-zone video cases — which would constitute actual unlawful command influence — could be used by attorneys in an attempt to get military courts to take another look at unrelated sexual assault convictions the Corps has secured, said attorneys tracking the issue.
link_name: Commandant's actions in scout sniper cases eyed by sex assault defense attorneys

status_message:
Today we salute Cpl. Ryan McSweeney, Lance Cpl. Joel Murray and the other Marines who helped repel a deadly attack in May on Forward Operating Base Shir Ghazi in Afghanistan.

The attack killed three Georgian soldiers, but the Marine Corps' role in repelling it was not widely known until a recent award ceremony at  Camp Leatherneck.
link_name: – New light shed on Marines' role in repelling attack on Forward Operating Base Shir Ghazi

status_message:
Insider attacks in Afghanistan are down in 2013, and there are a variety of reasons why. From the Associated Press:

"In its twice-a-year report to Congress this week, the Pentagon said insider attacks remain serious but are no longer the threat they were a year ago. At that time, a 120 percent rise in attacks from 2011 to 2012 threatened to derail the U.S. plan to leave small groups of trainers embedded among Afghan forces after the majority of troops withdraw by December 2014."
link_name: In Afghanistan, mixed reasons for drop in insider attacks

status_message: A change of command ceremony was held for III Marine Expeditionary Force in Japan today. Lt. Gen. Kenneth Glueck, who oversaw the Corps' renewal of the unit deployment program and the arrival of the first Osprey squadron in Japan relinquished command of III MEF, marking the dawn of a new era for Marines based on Okinawa.
link_name: New 3-star takes command of III MEF in Japan

status_message:
Col. James Christmas was removed as the commander of the 22nd Marine Expeditionary Unit on Wednesday, Marine officials said. They did not provide a reason, other than to say Maj. Gen. Raymond Fox, commander of II Marine Expeditionary Force, lost faith in his ability to lead Marines.

Christmas is a decorated combat veteran, and was the first commander of the Marine Corps' new crisis-response force for Africa this spring, while continuing to serve as the 22nd MEU commander. It is not clear whether he was relieved for actions related to leading the MEU, or the crisis-response force.
link_name: Commander of 22nd Marine Expeditionary Unit relieved of command

status_message:
Marine commanders at Camp Leatherneck, Afghanistan, asked in May 2010 for U.S. officials in Kabul to halt construction on a planned $34 million headquarters, deeming it too expensive and unnecessary. But the project went through anyway, leaving the base with a 64,000 square-foot facility that may never be used. It was completed last fall, as the U.S. drawdown there already was well underway.

How did this happen? What should be done with the building instead?
link_name: – D'oh! in the Desert: Why was an unwanted $34 million headquarters built at Camp Leatherneck?

Today was the final day of active-duty service for the top female Marine in the Corps. Maj. Gen. Angela Salinas kicked off her last day by dedicating the new Molly Marine statue at the National Museum of the Marine Corps. 
"People get to see her right down the walkway from 'Chesty' Puller and others from the legacy of our Corps," Salinas told Marine Corps Times. "It really gives women the credibility I think they've been looking for."
link_name: Top female Marine dedicates statue honoring women on her final day of service

status_message:
NEW TODAY: Commandant Gen. Jim Amos said this morning that the Marine Corps is bracing to cut another 8,000 Marines as a result of federally mandated budget cuts, leaving the service with an active-duty end strength of about 174,000.

Says the commandant: "As a result of sequestration, assuming this thing does not change, the Marine Corps is probably going to go down another 8,000. That's significant. We know what it is. We know what kind of units it will be. We know where it will come from across the United States. That's the reality of it."
link_name: Commandant: Marine Corps bracing to cut another 8,000 Marines

status_message:
While the Marine Corps continues to prosecute decorated scout snipers accused of urinating on dead Taliban fighters in Afghanistan, an officer in the unit has been released of all legal holds, promoted and selected to take over another battalion. He is Lt. Col. James B. Conway, the son of retired commandant Gen. James T. Conway.

This week's cover story goes inside the case and explores the charges of favoritism and nepotism that have been raised. Read more about it here on our Battle Rattle blog:

http://blogs.militarytimes.com/battle-rattle/2013/05/28/behind-the-cover-how-a-commandants-son-escaped-controversy-to-become-a-battalion-commander/

status_message:
The remains of 13 fallen service members killed in the last armed action of the Vietnam War were laid to rest May 15. The men died in a raid known as the Mayaguez Incident. 

Our thoughts are with the families and friends of: Privates 1st Class Daniel A. Benedett, Lynn Blessing, Walter Boyd, James J. Jacques, James R. Maxwell, Richard Rivenburgh, Antonio R. Sandoval and Kelton R. Turner; Lance Cpls. Gregory Copenhaver and Andres Garcia; Navy Hospitalmen Bernard Gause Jr. and Ronald J. Manning, and Air Force 2nd Lt. Richard Vandegeer.

Read more about the deadly raid and see a photo gallery from their burial at Arlington National Cemetery:
link_name: The Mayaguez incident: A farewell

status_message: The Naval Criminal Investigative Service in Okinawa, Japan, issued a warning to Marines following five reported cases of of a new brand of extortion. The cases involve women encouraging Marines to engage in online sexual activity, only to find out it was recorded. Then the criminals issue the threat: Marines are told to pay up or a copy will be sent to their commands.
link_name: Extortionists target Marines in online scams

status_message:
NEW TODAY: The Marine Corps is launching a new Security Augmentation Unit, which will be able to dispatch squad-level teams for immediate embassy security reinforcement. It will be made up of about 130 Marines who will be part of the Corps' Embassy Security Group based in Quantico, Va. 

The teams will respond directly to calls from the ambassador, chief of mission or regional security officer at the embassy.

Tell us what you think -- is this a good fix in the wake of the deadly attack in Benghazi, Libya?
link_name: Marine Corps adds new embassy security reinforcement teams

status_message:
Retired Marine Cpl. Ronny "Tony" Porta was badly burned when his Humvee hit an IED in Asad, Iraq. Six years later, he struggles with his disfigurement at home. 

A man recently approached Porta in a Home Depot and asked if he had been in a car accident. Porta told the man he was hit by an IED in Iraq. 

What really stuck with Porta and angers him still were the words the man said next: "Was it worth it?"
link_name: Disfigured Marine veteran faces disrespect at home

status_message: The Marine Corps Iwo Jima Memorial is one of 24 sites in Washington competing for $1 million in preservation funds. User votes will determine the site that receives the grant. Check out how you can help the memorial win the funding on Battle Rattle.
link_name: Marine Corps War Memorial in running for $1 million grant

status_message:
NEW TODAY: The Marine Corps has not only deployed its new crisis-response force for Africa, it is interested in developing a similar unit for use in the U.S. Southern Command area of operations. Commandant Gen. Jim Amos told Marine Corps Times.

"I'd personally like to see it out before the end of this calendar year," Amos said of the potential SOUTHCOM crisis-response force. "We just have to wait to see how the resources work out."
link_name: Corps' new crisis-response force deploys

status_message: Commandant Gen. Jim Amos said today that the Marine Corps' new crisis-response force for emergencies in Africa and Europe has begun to deploy, and will be based out of Morón Air Base, Spain.
link_name: Corps' new crisis-response force deploys

status_message:
Military Times' senior video journalist, Colin Kelly, recently met up with former sailor Ron White, who spent 10 months memorizing the name of every U.S. service member killed in Afghanistan. As a tribute, he writes each of their names from memory on a memorial he created. 

"The message I'm just trying to convey is that you're not forgotten," White said. "That I still remember you, and I'm going to keep your memory alive."
link_name: The Names

status_message:
This week's cover story is a can't-miss: We profiled Gen. James Mattis, the most revered Marine general in at least a generation. Mattis, the commander of U.S. Central Command, will retire soon, he confirmed to Marine Corps Times.

The story includes a variety of anecdotes about Mattis that you haven't heard before, thanks in part to interviews with Gen. John Kelly and others. It also includes new comments from Mattis himself.

For more details, check out our Battle Rattle blog here. Share this post on Facebook and get the word out.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Gen. James Mattis: 'Now it's time to go'

status_message:
Ten years have passed since the first major battle of Operation Iraqi Freedom. 

This weekend, hundreds of Marines who were there will return to reminisce about Nasiriyah. The six-day battle claimed 17 Marines and 11 soldiers; a Marine and a corpsman would receive the Navy Cross for valor. Remarkably, many of the warriors of Nasiriyah are still in the fight, a decade later.

http://militarytimes.com/blogs/battle-rattle/2013/03/15/nasiriyah-ten-years-later/

status_message: In case you missed it, Marine artilleryman and hot sauce baron Paul C.P. McIlhenny passed away this weekend. We've compiled a tribute to his world-famous Tabasco Sauce, an MRE favorite for decades, and his family's proud Marine Corps legacy. Check it out.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Tabasco executive and former Marine dies at 68

status_message:
Tonight, we remember Paul C.P. McIlhenny, a Marine artilleryman who later went into the family business: making Tabasco sauce. He died Saturday at 68. Mini Tabasco bottles, like the pair seen here, began appearing in troops' MREs during the 1990s. Over the years, thousands of deployed Marines have garnished their chow with McIlhenny's famous hot sauce — the condiment that became a battle buddy. Rest in peace, sir.

Read more on our Battle Rattle blog:
http://militarytimes.com/blogs/battle-rattle/2013/02/25/tabasco-executive-and-former-marine-dies-at-68/

(Photo by Andrew deGrandpre/Marine Corps Times)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Marine Lt. Col. Harold Burke thought DOD's Homeowners Assistance Program would ease the financial burden of owning a house in California that had lost more than $200,000 in value when he was forced to sell upon reassignment to Washington. Instead, he is left holding the bag for a $100,000 loan that's racking up hundreds of dollars in monthly interest. He burned through the family's savings and is selling off investments. Soon, he says, he'll eat into his kids' college funds. 

Read the full story on Marine Corps Times Prime:

status_message:
This week's issue of Marine Corps Times gives the scout snipers' perspective on the now infamous video showing them urinating on Taliban corpses.

One testified during his court-martial last week that the insurgents were heavily armed and ready to kill. The Marines suspected the three men on whom they urinated planted an IED that killed their friend weeks earlier, he said. 

Check out Battle Rattle for more on this story.
link_name: Behind the cover: Scout snipers on trial — here's their side

status_message: Statistics from all four military services show that from sexual assault and harassment to pornography, drugs and drinking, ethical lapses are an escalating problem among leaders. Your thoughts?
link_name: Sex is major reason military brass are fired

status_message: Here's the lowdown on Exercise Iron Fist, which will involve about 1,000 Marines with the 13th MEU and include mechanized training at Camp Pendleton, amphibious training on San Clemente Island and combined-arms training at Twentynine Palms.
link_name: Japanese troops to join Marines for training

status_message:
Maybe you remember Will Swenson. He's the Army captain who fought alongside then-Cpl. Dakota Meyer in Afghanistan, saving the lives of several Marines in the process. Swenson, a loud critic of Army officers who refused to send fire support that day, has never been honored for his heroism, and his Medal of Honor nomination was "lost" in Afghanistan until Gen. John Allen took an interest in the case.

An investigation into what happened is now complete, says Rep. Duncan Hunter. The results have not yet been disclosed.
link_name: Congressman: Medal of Honor probe complete

status_message:
In case you missed it -- Staff Sgt. Edward Deptola was reduced to the rank of sergeant during his court martial yesterday for his role in the infamous urination video.

The investigation also revealed 11 more videos Marines made that day, including while posing with casualties on a tank. Another two Marines could still face court-martial.
link_name: Corps: Urination video was 1 of 12 Marines made

status_message: NEW TONIGHT FROM CAMP LEJEUNE: Infamous urination video was just one of 12 that Marines made in Afghanistan, witnesses disclose during court-martial proceedings for Staff Sgt. Edward Deptola. He was busted in rank to sergeant for his role in the incident, though the judge recommended a much harsher sentence.
link_name: Corps: Urination video was 1 of 12 Marines made

status_message: Maj. Mark Thompson, a former instructor at the Naval Academy, is charged with aggravated sexual assault, fraternization and committing indecent acts in connection with a booze-fueled incident in 2011 that involved two female midshipmen.
link_name: Marine academy instructor accused of sexually assaulting student

status_message:
SUPER SOLDIERS AND MARINES: Our Pentagon correspondent reports this week that stunning advancements are emerging from the military's experimental research labs. Some are focused on giving troops super-acute hearing. Others aim to enhance tongues and taste buds, creating sonarlike sensors. Genetic engineers, meanwhile, are studying metabolism, and whether one day grunts in the field will be able to subsist on grass or other inedible items.

To read about these and other futuristic ideas DOD is exploring, visit Marine Corps Times Prime:
http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/prime/2013/01/PRIMEmilitary-super-soldier-technology-could-let-you-eat-grass-sleep-less-011513/

status_message: This is believed to be the first time British troops have been arrested on suspicion of murder over events alleged to have happened Afghanistan. The Brits have been based in Helmand province, alongside thousands of U.S. Marines.
link_name: U.K.: 7 Royal Marines arrested on suspicion of murder

status_message: Biden on putting troops on the ground in Syria: "The last thing America needs is to get involved in another ground war in the Middle East."

Biden said the Afghans are happy to let the U.S. keep doing the job in Afghanistan. Time for them to "step up." Ryan explains fighting season, contends that the drawdown of troops there has left Americans unsafe.

More Marines talk in the VP debate. Paul Ryan calls what Marines have done in Afghanistan "nothing short of amazing." Biden reinforces idea to get U.S. troops out by 2014. Said the responsibility in the transition lies on the Afghans. "We are leaving," Biden said. "We are leaving in 2014. Period."

The Vice Presidential candidates were asked if the U.S. should apologize for Marines urinating on Taliban corpses and Paul Ryan brings up the lack of Marine Security Forces in Libya on Sept. 11. Are you surprised Marines are a topic in tonight's debate?

NEW VIDEO! Thanks to Marcus McDowell for sending in a video he shot showing Pfc. Matthew Morgan running with Ben Baltz on his back to the finish line of a kids' triathlon. Ben is an 11-year-old amputee who lost his leg to bone cancer -- and the kid still participates in triathlons. 

Pretty touching Marine moment -- check it out here.
link_name: Marine steps in to help boy finish triathlon

status_message:
Check out this story on Pfc. Matthew Morgan. 

He was one of 22 Marines volunteering at a kids' triathlon this weekend when 11-year-old Ben Baltz, who lost part of his leg to bone cancer, had some trouble with his prosthetic. 

Morgan made sure Baltz made it to the finish line!
link_name: Marine steps in to help boy finish triathlon

"We haven't changed anything."

status_message: Several dozen veterans are running for U.S. House and Senate seats this year, but the number of former military members in public office has been declining for years. In 1969, nearly 90 percent of all U.S. House and Senate seats were held by people who'd served in uniform. Today, it's about 20 percent.
link_name: Many Iraq, Afghan vets choosing '2nd service'

status_message:
MARINES CONTINUE TO PUSH TALIBAN WITH RAIDS, EVEN AFTER DRAWDOWN:

To create breathing room for the Afghan units, the Marines continue to run raids into Taliban-held villages. The strategy allows coalition forces to keep enemy fighters off balance.

"You can pursue and attack the enemy in some depth, both by air and on ground," said Maj. Gen. David Berger. "It extends the ability to project power a little bit deeper and pursue the threat. You can push them back farther and farther from the population centers."
link_name: Marines shift focus as drawdown hits milestone

status_message: "Coalition and Afghan troops in Helmand also are bracing for the Taliban to test Afghan police and soldiers as it becomes clear they are in the lead in providing security in the region. In particular, insurgents have launched numerous attacks recently on Afghan National Security Forces in Sangin, Kajaki and Musa Qala, Gurganus said. All three districts are in northern Helmand, and home to fierce fighting in recent years."
link_name: Marines shift focus as drawdown hits milestone

status_message: Readers and fans, Marine Corps Times is sending senior writer Dan Lamothe and videographer/photographer Colin Kelly back to Afghanistan to embed with Marines for the month of October. Stay tuned for regular updates from them here and our blog, Battle Rattle.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Marine Corps Times to embed in Afghanistan in October

status_message:
UP NOW: A new, detailed look at what the Marine mission in Afghanistan looks like as the surge in U.S. forces there ends. 

Says Maj. Gen. Charles Gurganus, the top commander in Helmand province: 

"It used to be you could walk out of one of their [Afghan] patrol bases and see either a U.S. or U.K. flag flying in more than one direction, or maybe [an observation] balloon, and you can't see those things any more. It doesn't mean we've packed up and left them. It just means we've handed the lead in security to them in many places, and frankly, while they're a little bit nervous about it, they're managing to hold."
link_name: Marines shift focus as drawdown hits milestone

status_message: The Legged Squad Support System — a.k.a Robo-Mule — is an autonomous vehicle designed to lighten the load for infantry units. It can carry up to 400 pounds of equipment, including ammunition, batteries and water, reaching speeds of 8 mph during "burst" periods.

Japan-based Marines are testing a new inflatable shelter that hardens into a concrete structure within just 24 hours of being wet down. Known as Concrete Canvas, this proprietary material can be used to fortify sandbags and HESCO barriers, too, offering added protection from fragmentation, small-arms fire — even crummy weather.

NEW TONIGHT:
Two Camp Lejeune staff sergeants will be court-martialed in connection with the alleged desecration of Taliban corpses last year in Afghanistan. Among the charges against them: urinating on dead enemy fighters, posing for unofficial photographs with human casualties and being derelict in a host of duties.

status_message: On Sept. 2, a Marine Corps flag was raised at the U.S. embassy in Beirut, on a flagpole built with donations from former Marines who wanted to honor their brethren lost in Lebanon 28 years ago. Said Gen. James Mattis, who was in attendance: "To the maniacs who did this [and] who attacked our country on 9/11, who thought that by hurting us … they could scare us. They didn't understand Americans. They didn't understand that the Marines who fought at Iwo Jima and Fallujah do not scare. This enemy will not be successful."
link_name: Marine memorial in Lebanon provides closure

status_message:
NEW DETAILS IN CAMP BASTION ATTACK:
Lt. Col. Christopher Raible — the commanding officer of Marine Attack Squadron 211 who was killed last week along with Sgt. Bradley Atwell after 15 insurgents dressed as U.S. soldiers infiltrated the base — died while leading several other Marines in an aggressive counter attack as mayhem unfolded around them, according to media reports.
link_name: Report: Harrier squadron CO Lt. Col. Christopher Raible died leading counter attack after Camp Basti

status_message:
NEW TONIGHT: Our update on Friday's attack at Camp Bastion, which Lt. Col. Christopher Raible, 40, commanding officer of Marine Attack Squadron 211, and Sgt. Bradley Atwell, 27. 

In a phone interview with Marine Corps Times, Brig. Gen. Gregg Sturdevant, the top officer overseeing Marine aviation units in Afghanistan, credited personnel with 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing (Forward) with repelling the Taliban's attack. 

"Had they not done what they did, it could have been a lot of worse," Sturdevant said. "Obviously on the wing, we focus on fixing aircraft and flying those aircraft in support of ground forces. But, when forced to, we can quickly transition to offense on the ground, and that's exactly what happened Friday night."
link_name: Bastion attack kills squadron CO, sergeant

status_message:
'ROBO-MULE' VIDEO: 
The Marine Corps is evaluating "Robo-Mule" — also known as the Legged Squad Support System, which sounds decidedly less cool than "Robo-Mule." It's an autonomous vehicle whose animal-like body is designed to haul Marines' gear, even over rugged slopes and steep inclines.
link_name: 'Robo-mule' kicks up its heels for Marine Corps

status_message: Two Marines were hurt in a lightning strike last night at Twentynine Palms. A corpsman sustained comparatively minor injuries when he slipped down an embankment rushing to their aid.
link_name: Marines hit by lightning during desert training

status_message: We're 100 "likes" shy of reaching 13,000. Thanks to everyone for following Marine Corps Times.
A Fleet Antiterrorism Security Team, comprising some 50 Marines, will head to Libya and shore up security in the wake of last night's deadly attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi.
link_name: Pentagon boosting security at U.S. embassies

status_message: Pentagon officials say they are coordinating with the State Department on President Obama's order for increased security at U.S. embassies around the world.
link_name: Pentagon boosting security at U.S. embassies

status_message:
9/11 REMEMBERED:
Marine Corps Times' former managing editor Rob Colenso shared this image today. Never forget.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: A former Marine now working as a police investigator took a personal interest in finding another Marine's boot camp keepsake, which was stolen and pawned nearly a year ago. Props to Detective Tom Larsen.
link_name: Cop hunts down Marine's stolen boot camp ring

'TERMINAL LANCE TUESDAY'
We've released another Terminal Lance strip from Marine Corps Times' print archive. Check it out on our Battle Rattle blog.

VALOR AWARD APPROVED FOR 30,000 MARINES: 
Navy Secretary Ray Mabus has authorized the Navy Unit Commendation for personnel assigned to I Marine Expeditionary Force (Forward) between April 2010 and March 2011. 

Read the story on Marine Corps Times Prime:

status_message: Several defense experts on a panel discussing the defense and military aspects of the presidential campaign said both candidates offer similar visions for the next four years.
link_name: Candidates' differences on defense called minor

status_message: Check out this story from Camp Lejeune: Gunny Felix Rivera recently went to work as a psychiatric technician at the base naval hospital, where he was a patient for years while recovering from severe wounds sustained in Afghanistan. It's part of a new Navy program to help place wounded Marines into civilian jobs.
link_name: Program offers jobs for wounded Marines

status_message: U.S. drone strike believed responsible for taking out terror network's second in command in Yemen.
link_name: Al-Qaida's No. 2 in Yemen killed in airstrike

The list of contenders to replace your aged Humvees has been whittled to three. Check out our bumper-to-bumper report on each of the candidates vying to become the Corps' next light tactical vehicle. The story is available now on Marine Corps Times Prime.

http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/prime/2012/09/marine-corps-humvee-jltv-oshkosh-am-general-lockheed-090712

status_message: Iraq war hero, and Silver Star recipient, Maj. Christopher J. Bronzi takes command of 1st Battalion, 4th Marines, at Camp Pendleton.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Silver Star recipient takes command of 1/4

status_message: Did you guys see this? The White House has decided that Armed Forces Network will continue to air controversial conservative talk show host Rush Limbaugh despite a petition calling for his ouster. "We believe it is important that service members have access to a variety of viewpoints," a Pentagon spokesman said.
link_name: Limbaugh stays on AFN, White House declares

status_message: The commandant says he's weighing the value of homesteading more Marines — that is, limiting change-of-station moves in favor of keeping personnel assigned to one base or region beyond normal tour lengths. Doing so could save heaps of money. What do you think of that idea?
link_name: Marine Corps evaluates prospect of homesteading

status_message: Researchers see evidence that recent combat veterans — men and women in their 20s and 30s — appear to be growing old before their time. There are early signs of heart disease, diabetes, slowed metabolisms and obesity, conditions far more common to those middle aged or older.
link_name: War might be making young bodies old

status_message: In case you missed it, Marine Corps Times is opening its archive of "Terminal Lance" strips, posting vintage hilarity weekly over on our Battle Rattle blog. Check out "Tan-Belt Ninja," which went up earlier this week.
link_name: 'Terminal Lance' Tuesdays: The MCMAP novice and recruiting Max Uriarte to Marine Corps Times

status_message:
MARSOC is expanding, adding hundreds of elite special operators and support personnel. See what it takes to become the best of the best. Our recent cover story is available now on Marine Corps Times Prime.

Read it here:
http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/prime/2012/09/PRIME-marine-bigger-marsoc-despite-drawdown-090312
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: A DoD Inspector General report said its investigators were unable to make contact with roughly half of the 224 Installation Voter Assistance Offices at bases and posts worldwide. The Pentagon said those offices are all fully operational and the IG's findings are flawed because investigators were using an outdated contact list.
link_name: DoD pushes back on criticism of voting program

status_message: "I said a prayer and popped out to fire. I aimed straight for the murder hole they were firing from." — Cpl. Jason Hassinger, who used his M203 grenade launcher to quell an enemy ambush last year in northern Marjah. He'd been shot four times in the chest.
link_name: Marines receive Silver Stars for Afghanistan heroics

status_message: Our thoughts are with the family and friends of Lance Cpl. Alec Terwiske, KIA Afghanistan, Sept. 3, 2012.
link_name: Family: Marine from Ind. killed in Afghanistan

status_message: Cultural curiosity alert: Check out the military-only fan club for the '80s cartoon series "My Little Pony." These dudes call themselves Bronies -- a mash up of "bro" and "pony."
link_name: Bronies in uniform — and proud of it

status_message: Does the Marine Corps have a drinking problem? The service's behavioral health experts say yes, but they're having a tough time selling the brass on a new alcohol awareness plan.
link_name: Marine Corps developing new plan to get troops to drink less

link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Lt. Gen. John Kelly: 'I don't know why they hate us, and

status_message: Commandant Gen. Jim Amos says that if sequestration occurs, it will have a disproportionately large effect on the Marine Corps because the service is smaller.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – For service chiefs, sequestration question doesn't go aw

status_message: The Marine Corps is considering an admin sep for a Lejeune lance corporal who was engaged to reality TV's Jenelle Evans, one of the four women featured on MTV's "Teen Mom 2." He pleaded guilty Monday to assaulting her back in June. The Corps cited a "pattern of misconduct."
link_name: Marine, ex of reality TV star, faces separation

status_message: Sgt. Maj. Henry Black, 7th sergeant major of the Marine Corps, was buried today at Quantico National Cemetery with full military honors. In the photo here, Sergeant Major of the Marine Corps Mike Barrett presents his family with a U.S. flag.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Remembering Henry Black, 7th sergeant major of the Marin

status_message:
Check out our in-depth profile of Gen. Joe Dunford, the SECDEF's reported choice to lead the war in Afghanistan starting next year. Says one of his contemporaries: "He has that street sense, that street fighter in him with a disciplined, Irish-inspired point of view."

This story is available on Marine Corps Times Prime:
http://marinecorpstimes.com/prime/2012/08/marine-general-joe-dunford-war-chief-isaf-nominee-afghanistan-082812/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: SEAL's forthcoming book detailing the mission to eliminate Osama bin Laden raises questions about the original narrative describing the terror kingpin's final moments alive.
link_name: SEAL book raises questions on bin Laden's death

status_message: Former Marine Capt. Austin Tice, an Afghanistan combat vet turned freelance journalist, went missing two weeks ago while on assignment in Syria. In one of his last posts on Twitter, Tice wrote: "Listening to the shells usher in my birthday. Afghanistan, California, DC, Egypt, Turkey, Syria. What an insane year." Please keep Austin and his family in your thoughts.
link_name: Reporter, former Marine officer, missing for two weeks in Syria

status_message: At least two female Marines will participate in the Infantry Officers Course this fall, Gen. Jim Amos told reporters today while acknowledging that the issue has created waves within the service. "I need to get past hyperbole and get past intuition and instincts," the commandant said. "I need to get facts."
link_name: Commandant Amos ready for women to attend IOC

status_message: Navy Times is giving away six copies of "Battleship" on Blu-Ray and DVD. Share their photo for a chance to win.
link_name: Navy Times

status_message: A memorial service will be held for Sgt. Maj. Henry Black, the seventh sergeant major of the Marine Corps, on Wednesday morning at the U.S. Marine Memorial Chapel at Quantico. Rest in peace.
link_name: Henry Black, 7th SMMC, dies at 83

status_message: In this 2009 photograph, Sgt. Maj. Henry Black, the seventh sergeant major of the Marine Corps, speaks with Sgt. Maj. Carlton Kent, then the Corps' top enlisted Marine. Black died Friday at 83. Kent tells Marine Corps Times he considered him a father figure and mentor. Rest in peace.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: The Marine Corps family mourns the loss of Henry Black, the seventh sergeant major of the Marine Corps. He earned the Silver Star for heroism as a junior Marine in Korea, and pulled two combat tours in Vietnam. Rest in peace.
link_name: Henry Black, 7th SMMC, dies at 83

status_message:
Marines, we want to hear from you. Tell us what you think of your superiors. Are leaders too hard on their Marines? Or would you prefer to see more discipline in the ranks with tougher leadership? Tell us what is working and what isn't.

Email your responses to: gharkins@marinecorpstimes.com
link_name: Are leaders doing a good job? Tell us

status_message: BREAKING TODAY: The Marine Corps has decided not to press criminal charges against three of the Marines depicted in a viral video urinating on dead Taliban fighters. They've been NJP'ed instead.
link_name: No courts-martial in Marine urination scandal

status_message:
In case you missed it this weekend and you need some motivation to get your week started -- check out Staff Sgt. Mark Zambon's story. Zambon lost his legs in an IED blast last January. He climbed Africa's highest mountain just last month at the pace of an able-bodied climber. 

Read his story here:
http://marinecorpstimes.com/news/2012/08/marine-kilimanjaro-climb-amputee-eod-mark-zambon-082512w/

About 200 Marines are in Guatemala working with the local navy to stop drug traffickers.
