status_message: Check out this story about Staff Sgt. Mark Zambon. He's an EOD tech who lost both of his legs in an IED attack last January. That didn't stop this Marine from climbing more than 19,000 feet to the top of Africa's highest mountain.
link_name: Amputee EOD tech tackles Africa's tallest peak

status_message: Congratulations to Gunnery Sgt. Joseph Lurz, who received the Silver Star today for heroism in Afghanistan with Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command. Read more about Lurz and the future of MARSOC in next week's Marine Corps Times.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Headquarters staff with 1st Marine Division (Forward) returned to Camp Pendleton this week, highlighting that the current phase of the Marine drawdown in Afghanistan is nearing completion.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Current phase of Marine drawdown in Afghanistan nears co

status_message: "This is a public issue. For every person who commits suicide, there's a family affected by it for a lifetime," said Tom Mahany, a former West Point cadet who served as a specialist second class in Vietnam in 1969.
link_name: Vet on hunger strike to spur action on suicides

status_message: UPDATE: The Marine vet who was committed to a psychiatric facility after the feds found anti-government commentary on his Facebook page was released and allowed to go home.
link_name: Judge orders release of detained Marine vet

status_message: SEAL book drama Day 2. Now the author has been identified, prompting concerns for his safety. It was reported yesterday that he could face legal trouble if the book divulges classified information.
link_name: SEAL who wrote bin Laden raid book identified

status_message: Commandant Gen. Jim Amos addressed today speculation that Gen. Joseph Dunford, his assistant commandant, could become the next commander of the war in Afghanistan.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Commandant on Dunford-to-Afghanistan speculation: 'I lik

status_message: Ladies: The Marine Corps has issued a news release on how to attain the perfect hair bun. All you need is a sock to roll up in your hair.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Female Marines' hairstyling secret exposed

status_message:
"Under heavy volumes of machine gun and rocket propelled grenade fire he remained composed, directing the fires of his men and the commandos, maximizing the effectiveness of their organic weapons and focusing the element's firepower onto the most lethal enemy positions. When the team's original team leader was wounded and evacuated, Gunnery Sergeant Lurz seamlessly assumed command and aggressively employed the unit during the remaining five months of the deployment." 

-- From the award citation for Gunnery Sgt. Joseph Lurz, new Silver Star recipient
link_name: MARSOC gunnery sgt. to get Silver Star

status_message: Gunnery Sgt. Joseph Lurz's actions led to the "neutralization" of more than 100 insurgents and countless IEDs, according to his Silver Star citation. He'll receive the award at Camp Lejeune on Friday. 'Rrrrrrah! Pass it on.
link_name: MARSOC gunny to receive Silver Star

status_message: A member of SEAL Team 6 is publishing a firsthand tell-all on the mission to take out al Qaida kingpin Osama bin Laden. As you might suspect, this is creating a storm in Washington, where there is deep concern the book will divulge classified information about the secretive operation last year in Pakistan.
link_name: Book on bin Laden raid coming out Sept. 11

status_message: Could Assistant Commandant Gen. Joseph Dunford become the next commander of the war in Afghanistan? A new Wall Street Journal report suggests it the case.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Gen. Joseph Dunford frontrunner to lead Afghan war, repo

status_message: Several Marines with the 24th MEU are credited with rushing to the scene of April's MV-22 Osprey crash in Morocco and risking their lives to retrieve the aircraft's pilots, who survived, and crew chiefs, who did not.
link_name: Report details heroism in Osprey crash aftermath

status_message:
Check it out: This is "The Human Backpack," an Israeli-designed harness that allows an able-bodied Marine to sling a wounded comrade over his shoulders and continue using both hands for aiming and firing his weapon, fighting, climbing and so forth. Select Marine units are fielding it now.

Read about it on Marine Corps Times Prime:
http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/prime/2012/08/PRIMEmarine-casualty-sling-human-backpack-082112/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Members of the 24th MEU are training troops in Uganda for their upcoming deployment to Somalia. While teaching them about urban warfare, the Marines there are learning about fighting in a jungle environment, something this generation hasn't really experienced.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Members of the 24th MEU train troops heading to Somalia

status_message: This is something else here: A First Amendment debate has begun over the psychiatric detention of a 26-year-old Marine vet who made anti-government statements on Facebook.
link_name: Marine vet detained for strident Facebook posts

status_message: Our thoughts are with the families and friends of Staff Sgt. Gregory Copes and Hospitalman 1st Class Darrel Enos, KIA Afghanistan, 8/17/12. Both men were members of MARSOC's 3rd Special Operations Battalion, out Camp Lejeune. They were killed by an Afghan policeman.
link_name: MARSOC IDs Marine, corpsman killed in attack

status_message: EXCLUSIVE: We have an early look at Medal of Honor recipient's explosive new book, "Into the Fire." If you share one story on Facebook today, please consider making it this one.
link_name: Dakota Meyer blasts Army brass in new book

status_message:
"We both knew it was over. I drew back my arm and drove the stone down, crushing his left cheekbone. He went limp. I pushed up on my knees and hit him with more force. The blow caved in the left side of his forehead. I smashed his face again and again, driven by pure primal rage."

-- Medal of Honor recipient Dakota Meyer, describing hand-to-hand combat he says he encountered in Ganjgal, Afghanistan.
link_name: Dakota Meyer blasts Army brass in new book

status_message: Medal of Honor recipient Dakota Meyer met with Marine Corps Times senior writer Dan Lamothe to discuss his forthcoming book. Read about it here.
link_name: Dakota Meyer blasts Army brass in new book

status_message:
"Some of our guys have seven, eight, nine combat tours. They're very, very experienced in terms of what they do. When you lose a guy like that, that's hard. But you know what? There are 10 other men who will step up and do his job if we ask him to. They're amazingly resilient in terms of what they're doing." 

-- Maj. Gen. Paul Lefebvre, MARSOC commander
link_name: 2 more MARSOC operators dead in attack

status_message: Sources say that the two U.S. troops killed by an Afghan police officer Friday were with Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command. Our thoughts and prayers are with their families.
link_name: 2 more MARSOC operators dead in attack

status_message: Here's the cover of this week's Marine Corps Times, on newsstands now.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: EXCLUSIVE: The Marine Corps is investigating an anomaly with how recruits are taught about the GI Bill at boot camp. An audit has revealed that thousands are still paying $100/month into the old Montgomery plan — even though the new Post-9/11 program is free.
link_name: USMC investigates boot camp GI Bill anomaly

status_message: Thousands of re-enlistment-eligible NCOs and staff NCOs can do so significantly sooner, thanks to a recently announced update to the Corps' fiscal 2013 re-up rules.
link_name: Corps expands re-up window for thousands

status_message: Disturbing new details have emerged in the Aug. 10 killing of three Marines aboard FOB Delhi in Garmser, Afghanistan.
link_name: Report: Deadly attack on Marines was carried out by unvetted Afghan teen

status_message: Taliban leader contends that insurgents loyal to him have infiltrated Afghan army and police units across the country.
link_name: Taliban: We have infiltrated Afghan forces

status_message: ARTA BEACH, Djibouti– Marines with the 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit navigate an obstacle during a water obstacle course at Arta Beach in Djibouti, Aug. 11, 2012.
link_name: Line Of Sight Photo Blog - Military Times – Djibouti Water Obstacle

status_message: In case you missed it: Smoke the donkey, who befriended Marines in Iraq and later came to live in the U.S., has died. Our thoughts are with Smoke's caretaker and all of the Marines with 1st CLB who knew and cared for him.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Smoke the donkey, beloved Marine mascot dies

status_message: The commandant has distributed a letter intended for all Marines and their families, urging caution and calm in the wake of Friday's attacks in Afghanistan that left six Marines dead and at least two others wounded. Gen. Jim Amos says the Taliban is attempting to "drive a wedge" between Marines and their Afghan allies.
link_name: Top Marine urges caution, calm after deadly Afghan attacks

status_message: U.S. Marines with the 2nd Platoon, Charlie Company, 2nd Reconnaissance Battalion, 26th Marine Expeditionary Unit (MEU) engage steel targets with fragmenting ammunition during a live fire exercise as a part of the 26th MEU's predeployment training program. (DoD photo by Cpl. Christopher Q. Stone, U.S. Marine Corps/Released)
link_name: Line Of Sight Photo Blog - Military Times – Predeployment Training for 26th MEU

status_message: The much-loved Marine mascot, Smoke -- the donkey with a love for eating lit cigarettes -- who came all the way from Iraq, has died.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Smoke the donkey, beloved Marine mascot dies

status_message: A spike in so-called green-on-blue attacks has prompted U.S. officials in Afghanistan to revamp the screening process for Afghan recruits and identify new ways to protect U.S. troops, officials said.
link_name: Inside-the-wire attacks double in Afghanistan

status_message: If you like The Onion, then you'll love The Duffel Blog. A former infantryman, Sgt. Paul Szoldra, created the site full of fake, so-outrageous-it-could-be-real military news.
link_name: Satirical military news site fools readers

status_message:
Col. Terri Erdag (pictured), former commander of the Marine Corps Combat Service Support Schools, was fired from that post in April after a subordinate complained about the colonel's alleged romantic advances, according to a Marine Corps investigation.

Read more at Marine Corps Times Prime:
http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/prime/2012/08/marine-erdag-terri-col-harassment-foia-081312/

status_message: Two atheist groups, and one advocating religious freedom, have petitioned the SECNAV for access to Camp Pendleton. The organizations are taking specific aim at the Calvary Chapel Costa Mesa, alleging this controversial organization receives preferential treatment from the base.
link_name: Atheists contest treatment from Camp Pendleton

status_message:
Our thoughts are with the families and friends of the six Marines killed Friday in Afghanistan. They are:
* Capt. Matthew P. Manoukian
* Gunnery Sgt. Ryan Jeschke
* Staff Sgt. Sky R. Mote
* Staff Sgt. Scott E. Dickinson
* Cpl. Richard A. Rivera Jr.
* Lance Cpl. Gregory T. Buckley
link_name: Pentagon IDs 6 Marines killed in Helmand

status_message: The top enlisted Marine, Sgt. Maj. Mike Barrett, is cautioning re-enlistment-eligible corporals and sergeants in the infantry to think twice before taking the new $25,000 "operational force kicker." Doing so, he said, could have consequences for career-minded Marines.
link_name: Sgt. Maj. cautions grunts about $25K bonus

status_message: Here's more on this week's issue of Marine Corps Times, which draws on a long interview with Medal of Honor recipient Dakota Meyer as he prepares for the release of his new book.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Behind the Cover: In new book, Dakota Meyer unloads

status_message: Anthony Swofford, author of "Jarhead," talks to Marine Corps Times about his new project, which chronicles his life of temptation and excess following the success of his breakout project. A former scout sniper, Swofford served in the Corps during the first Gulf War.
link_name: 'Jarhead' author examines post-combat pitfalls

status_message: The three MARSOC casualties reported Friday in Sangin district were among six U.S. deaths perpetrated that same day in Afghanistan's Helmand province — allegedly by Afghan allies, officials tell The Associated Press. The other three U.S. troops were killed late last night in Garmser district, where Marine forces have operated for years.
link_name: 6 Americans killed in one day in Afghanistan

status_message: More air ops, live-fire training and brigade-size exercises, involving 15,000 Marines. That's the Corps' interest in expanding Twentynine Palms. Will it have any effect on day-to-day life for Marines and families stationed there?
link_name: Study backs plan for Twentynine Palms growth

status_message: Gunnery Sgt. Verice Bennett, a Silver Star recipient, got to watch his brother, Ashton Eaton, win an Olympic gold medal yesterday! Check out the story on Battle Rattle:
link_name: Silver and gold: Two brothers earn very different medals

status_message: The three U.S. troops killed in Afghanistan today by a man in an Afghan army uniform were with Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command.
link_name: 3 killed in Afghanistan were spec ops Marines

status_message: Military officials are investigating the shooting deaths of three U.S. troops in Afghanistan's Helmand province, where thousands of Marines are based. The victims have not been identified, pending notification of their families.
link_name: 3 U.S. troops killed by man in Afghan army uniform

status_message: VIDEO: Coming Monday in Marine Corps Times, Marine Medal of Honor recipient Dakota Meyer discusses his forthcoming book "Into the Fire." Here's a small excerpt from the interview.
link_name: Dakota Meyer; Book Revelations

status_message:
"That right there was rock bottom. I could never get lower than that, you know? And seeing how close it was that I was to take my own life, I think it's something that a lot of veterans go through coming back and dealing with the realities of war."  

-- Sgt. Dakota Meyer, Medal of Honor recipient
link_name: Dakota Meyer attempted suicide, book reveals

status_message: Walter Reed Medical Center swept for explosives after bomb threat yesterday. The facility was closed for three hours.
link_name: Bomb threat at Walter Reed forces short closure

status_message: Our thoughts are with the family and friends of Petty Officer 3rd Class Clayton R. Beauchamp, KIA Afghanistan, 8/7/12.
link_name: IED kills sailor in Helmand

status_message: BREAKING: Medal of Honor recipient Dakota Meyer tried to kill himself in 2010, according to his forthcoming book. He met with Marine Corps Times' Dan Lamothe on Tuesday to discuss this and other stunning revelations contained in "Into the Fire: A Firsthand Account of the Most Extraordinary Battle in the Afghan War," which is scheduled for release next month. We'll have much, much more in our next issue, coming to newsstands Monday.
link_name: Dakota Meyer attempted suicide, book reveals

status_message: Our thoughts are with the family and friends of Cpl. Daniel L. Linnabary II, KIA Afghanistan, 8/6/12.
link_name: Lejeune Marine dies in Afghanistan

status_message: Feds are looking into who leaked the Marine Corps' call for a laser to be used in Iraq that could cause "instantaneous burst-combustion of insurgent clothing" five years after the info got out.
link_name: Battle Rattle - Feds investigating five-year-old leak of Marine-desired weapon

status_message: The new command slate is out. Did your favorite colonel make the list?
link_name: 56 colonels selected for command assignments

status_message: The Marine Corps has announced selective early retirement boards for lieutenant colonels and colonels, a move that's intended to help the service clear out a promotion bottleneck at its most-senior ranks. This story appears on Marine Corps Times Prime, a new home for exclusive content previously available only in our weekly newspaper.
link_name: 'Surplus' officers: Retire early or risk SERB

status_message: In case you missed it over the weekend, we've taken a closer look at MARSOC's low-profile mission in Afghanistan's Badghis province, where three Marine critical skills operators were killed within five days in late July. This story is available via Marine Corps Times Prime, our new home for content previously available only in our weekly newspaper.
VIDEO: A collector in Annapolis, Md., is looking to sell his Vietnam era Huey — on Craigslist. Is there space on your property for this war relic?
link_name: Craigslist Huey

status_message: Here's the cover of this week's Marine Corps Times, on newsstands now. The cover story examines a highly anticipated facet of the coming drawdown: voluntary separation pay.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: You might have seen this photo floating around the Internet and wondered about this Marine. Here's the story: Former Sgt. Mark Dolfini stood outside the hospital room of 12-year-old Cody Green, a boy who battled cancer for 10 years. Dolfini stood guard for Green, who loved the Marine Corps, during his final hours on Earth.
link_name: Watch-standing sgt. honors child with cancer

status_message: Here's the backstory to last month's viral video showing deployed Marines at Kandahar Airfield dancing to "Call me Maybe." It's been watched more than 400,000 times on YouTube — but, as many of you know, the production didn't go over so well with some in the infantry community.
link_name: Video renews grunt vs. nongrunt rivalry

status_message: The unemployment rate for veterans who entered service after Sept. 11, 2001, fell to 8.9 percent in July, down from 9.5 percent the previous month and from 12.4 percent in July 2011, according to the latest monthly employment report released Friday by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
link_name: Vets' unemployment rate improves again in July

status_message: ADVICE FROM A 1ST SGT: Jermain Jenkins authored this book to help junior Marines navigate certain personal and professional pitfalls. We sought his leadership tips for junior Marines and NCOs. What are the best — and worst — things you learned from senior enlisted Marines?
link_name: First Sgt's book aims to help Marines dodge pitfalls

status_message: MARSOC lost three critical skills operators in five days in late July: Gunnery Sgts. Daniel J. Price and Jonathan W. Gifford and Sgt. Justin M. Hansen. This story, which will appear on newsstands in Monday's Marine Corps Times, examines the complicated mission they were undertaking in northwestern Afghanistan's Badghis province. It's available now on Marine Corps Times Prime.
link_name: MARSOC deaths underscore threat in Badghis

status_message: The Marine Corps announced that fallen scout sniper, Sgt. Matthew Abbate, will be posthumously awarded the Navy Cross next Friday. Abbate was KIA six weeks after the battle that earned him the combat award.
link_name: Fallen Marine's family to accept Navy Cross

status_message: Our thoughts are with the family and friends of Lance Cpl. Curtis J. Duarte, KIA, Afghanistan, Aug.1, 2012.
link_name: Twentynine Palms Marine dies in Afghanistan

status_message: Get the lowdown on "MuscleFest" at 8th & I. Yeah, there's a photo of a staff sergeant lifting a 2.25-ton Chevy Silverado. What? You thought only gunnies could lift pickup trucks?
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Marine Barracks Washington completes 'MuscleFest'

status_message: The Corps honored a special Marine on Friday. Retired Col. Richard Rothwell, who recently passed away, was one of only five infantry battalion commanders who landed with their units and survived the 36-day Battle of Iwo Jima. Check out his amazing career.
link_name: Iwo Jima Marine memorialized in final salute

status_message: In case you missed it, this week's cover story is now available on Marine Corps Times Prime. This new home for exclusive content contains stories previously available only in our weekly newspaper. It's free for subscribers. Non-subscribers can buy a day pass for 99 cents.

Only three to go now!

status_message: Health care professionals at Camp Lejeune, N.C., say they're seeing positive results from a new form of therapy that aims to treat Marines who suffer from insomnia and anxiety.
link_name: The art of relaxation

status_message: BREAKING: It appears that sequestration, if it happens in January, won't drive additional military personnel cuts. However, by exempting DOD's account for pay and benefits from these once unimaginable across-the-board reductions, the Obama administration would have to make even deeper cuts to other defense programs.
link_name: Personnel programs exempt from sequestration

status_message: A congressionally mandated report maps out new recommendations for realigning Marine forces throughout the Pacific. Who's excited for Guam deployments?
link_name: Report: Move fewer Marines to Guam, but get it done now

status_message: The Corps' lone Olympian, Sgt. Jamel Herring, "remained clear-eyed and strong" despite his defeat Tuesday in London. "The people at home told me, no matter the result, I am still a hero, I am still a champion," he said. "I'm going to take that confidence and uplift myself."
link_name: NY Marine loses bout to Kazakh at Olympics

status_message: With "extraordinarily high" recruiting and retention, and current pay levels that have troops well compensated in comparison to their civilian peers, a new Rand Corp. report suggests there would be little harm in limiting military pay increases to a level below the average annual growth in private-sector pay. Do you agree?
link_name: Report: Time is right to downsize pay raises

status_message: The commandant has approved a plan to speed the approval process for all valor awards. Commanders up and down the chain will face new pressure to ensure paperwork is started and completed in a timely fashion, and new authority has been given to deployed generals and colonels.
link_name: CMC orders quicker processing of valor awards

status_message: Who killed Kenny? Looks like it might have been Stan.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – South Park's Stan in Afghanistan: The untold story

status_message: Our thoughts are with the families and friends of Gunnery Sgt. Daniel J. Price and Gunnery Sgt. Jonathan W. Gifford, KIA, Badghis province, Afghanistan, July 29, 2012.
link_name: Decorated MARSOC gunnies killed in Afghanistan

status_message: And finally, it can be told: Here's the story of how South Park's Stan Marsh made his way around Marjah, Afghanistan.
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – South Park's Stan in Afghanistan: The untold story

status_message: We are 50 "likes" shy of 12,000!
Here's the cover of this week's Marine Corps Times, on newsstands now. The cover story is a must-read for those nearing the end of their active service.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Animal-rights advocates and others have long criticized the military's use of live animals for teaching corpsmen and Marines how to treat trauma patients. A new study suggests modern simulators can do the job better. What do you think?
link_name: Will sims replace animals in trauma training?

status_message: The Corps' warrant officer community won't see the same force-shaping efforts that will affect the enlisted and officer ranks as the service sheds some 5,000 Marines from active-duty over the next four years. The promotion outlook for WOs will remain steady, Marine officials say.
link_name: Warrant officers largely immune to drawdown

status_message: THE CORPS' NEW 4-STAR. For anyone who's keeping score, Lt. Gen. John Kelly's promotion gives the service five four-star general officers. (Allen, Amos, Dunford and Mattis being the others.) Kelly is set to take over at U.S. Southern Command, where he'll have his hands full overseeing military activity in a region faced with drug trafficking, natural disasters, humanitarian crises and cyber threats.
link_name: Marine Corps general to take over at SOUTHCOM

status_message: Gen. Marty Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, casts doubt on potential U.S. military involvement in Syria, favoring diplomatic pressure instead. "My job is to provide options, and I have been working on plans," he said. "None of them are at an executable level of detail at this point."
link_name: Dempsey: U.S. military action in Syria unlikely

status_message: Staff Sgt. Paul Worley talks to Marine Corps Times about the 2010 mission in Afghanistan for which he was awarded the Silver Star. He was wounded in the battle, taking an enemy round to his thigh. When a lieutenant relayed by radio that higher command wanted him evacuated, "I told them f--- no, that I was busy," Worley said.
link_name: Pendleton staff sgt. talks about Silver Star

status_message: The state of Wisconsin has been asked to drop the hammer on a former maintenance worker at one its veterans cemeteries who's accused of using the site as his personal trash dump. Garbage removed from the site includes cans of paint thinner, mattresses and furniture. About 8,400 veterans and nearly 1,900 spouses have been laid to rest in the cemetery south of Milwaukee.
link_name: Charges sought in veterans cemetery trash dump

status_message: Friends: We added nearly 100 "likes" this week, bringing us within striking distance of 12,000. Next week is our week. Thanks to all who read and support Marine Corps Times.

U.S. Ambassador to Afghanistan Ryan Crocker was pinned with the eagle, globe and anchor and named an Honorary Marine in a ceremony led by Gen. John Allen. Crocker is retiring after a 41-year-long career as a diplomat.
link_name: U.S. ambassador to Afghanistan named Honorary Marine

status_message: The Defense Department needs special protection from across-the-board spending cuts that threaten to reduce military manpower by another 100,000 troops, a leading Republican in Congress said Thursday, adding that the economy is too fragile to send so many more veterans into an already bleak job market. Your thoughts?
link_name: Sequestration could mean another 100K-troop cut

status_message: Meet Staff Sgt. Christen Wagner, who represented the Marine Corps at this year's Reebok CrossFit games in California. She snatches 162 pounds, back squats 285 and adheres to a strict Paleolithic diet. Read more on our Battle Rattle blog:
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Female Marine Competes in 2012 CrossFit Competition

status_message: OLYMPIC MARINE: The Corps' lone athlete in London is Sgt. Jamel Herring, a member of the U.S. Boxing Team. Check out our profile — and wish him well in his quest for Gold.
link_name: Meet the athletes: Boxing

status_message: READ THIS WEEK'S COVER STORY: Get the lowdown on which ranks and MOSs have been hit hardest by the Marine Corps' drawdown promotion freeze. This story is now available on Marine Corps Times Prime, the new home for exclusive content previously available only in our weekly newspaper.

status_message: An AV-8B Harrier crashed today near MCAS Yuma, Ariz., but Marine officials report the pilot ejected safely.

status_message: A former sergeant will spend 30 days in jail following his conviction in the strangling death of a nine-month kitten. The incident and subsequent legal proceedings coincided with the end of his Marine Corps career.

status_message: President Obama has announced plans to launch a new website listing the names of those who have earned the nation's highest combat valor awards, an attempt to stifle would-be fakers from claiming medals they didn't earn. "It may no longer be a crime for con artists to pass themselves off as heroes," he said Monday, "but one thing is certain — it is contemptible."
link_name: President: New website will aim to deter fakers

status_message: "When he would come home, he would watch old videos of him and his brother and sister, and go through old photo albums. He just loved that. He loved the comfort of our family. We're a military family, and we've moved over 25 times. To us, our comfort level was being together." -- Karen Kelly, mother of fallen 1st Lt Robert Kelly and wife of Lt. Gen. John Kelly
link_name: Fallen lieutenant remembered with scholarship

status_message: The Marine Corps Times Facebook community is closing in on 12,000. Will we make it by week's end? Our sincere thanks to all for your continued interest and support. Onward to 12K!

The White House has big plans to overhaul the Transition Assistance Program, which all troops must undertake before leaving the service. No more "death by PowerPoint," officials promise. The new-and-improved TAP will put greater emphasis on helping new vets set out on civilian career paths that fits their individual goals while optimizing the skills they learned in the military. MCAS Miramar, Calif., will be among the test sites.
link_name: More assistance expected with update to TAP

status_message: About half of the service members who marched in Saturday's gay pride parade in San Diego did so in uniform after the Pentagon gave a one-time exception to its rule barring troops from wearing uniforms in parades.
link_name: Wearing uniform at gay parade a personal choice

status_message: Here's our profile of 19-year-old Kristen Trout, who earlier this month received the 1st Lt. Robert M. Kelly Memorial Scholarship. Kelly was killed in combat Nov. 9, 2010. He's the son of Lt. Gen. John Kelly, the most senior U.S. officer to lose a child in Iraq or Afghanistan. Trout has grown close to the Kelly family, and now wears a bracelet engraved with the lieutenant's name, final unit and a thankful tribute. "Semper Fi," it reads. "You changed my life forever."
link_name: Fallen lieutenant remembered with scholarship

status_message: Did you know it's against the rules to fiddle with your iPod while you're driving on base? The PMO at Camp Pendleton is cracking down on all manner of distracted driving. status_message: Friends, this is why we love lance corporals. Get a load of this guy. Mike Bruce, known to his friends as "The Machine," is angling to break one of the most obscure world records we've ever heard of — bending steel bars across his neck. "The Marine Corps gave me the ability to realize that as long as you never quit, you're never going to be a failure," Bruce says. Get some, buddy.
link_name: Strong-necked leatherneck aims for bizarre world record

status_message:
"I am [damned] proud of this MEB team, they fought and thought their way through endless challenging scenarios in this most complex COIN environment we call Afghanistan. They have surely added a few lines of honor and accomplishment to the storied history of our Corps." 

-- Maj. Gen. Larry Nicholson, on the MEB he commanded in Afghanistan
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Maj. Gen. Larry Nicholson on MEB-Afghanistan's President

status_message:
Maj. Gen. Larry Nicholson shares his thoughts on MEB-Afghanistan getting the Presidential Unit Citation:

"Could not be prouder of our team or more honored by the Presidential recognition for the members of the MEB. The success of the MEB came at great cost and we will never forget the heroes who were killed and wounded. The MEB Team possessed an expeditionary mindset to get out and be in and amongst the people every day. MEB lived a rugged and Spartan lifestyle, and stayed closely connected to the local population they were there to protect. They put it all on the line every day and they never wavered. I am [damned] proud of this MEB team, they fought and thought their way through endless challenging scenarios in this most complex COIN environment we call Afghanistan. They have surely added a few lines of honor and accomplishment to the storied history of our Corps."
link_name: Battle Rattle - A Marine Corps Times Blog – Maj. Gen. Larry Nicholson on MEB-Afghanistan's President

status_message: BREAKING TONIGHT: Sgt. Matthew T. Abbate is the latest Marine to be honored with the Navy Cross. He was killed in combat six weeks later.

status_message:
In case you missed it, the use of "bath salts" among Marines is a big-time worry for the Corps because standard drug screens can't detect it. Producing a high comparable to cocaine and methamphetamine, these products are readily available off-base in gas stations and convenience stores. 

And you've no-doubt heard about the guy in Miami who was shot and killed by police last month as he chewed off the face of a homeless man. Initial reports suggest the attacker was high on bath salts.
link_name: Growing use of 'bath salts' concerns Corps

In case you missed it, a top researcher is taking issue with the Marine Corps' requirements for body armor, saying the service should be willing to accept greater risk in exchange for cutting weight and improving the mobility of those who wear it in combat. 

"A real warrior," says the Office of Naval Research's George Solhan, "would like to go to combat with a weapon, a loin cloth and a light coat of oil."
link_name: Researcher rips USMC body armor requirement

status_message: Former Marine Sgt. George "Loaded" Lockhart is back on the MMA circuit, pummeling opponent Jarome Hatch on Friday at Showdown Fights in Salt Lake City. "The win showed a lot of dominance," Lockhart tells Marine Corps Times' military sports blogger, Phil Creed. Readers may remember Lockhart, a former MCMAP instructor trainer, who was the subject of a cover story two years ago when the Corps denied his invitation to appear on Spike TV's "Ultimate Fighter." It's great to see Loaded Lockhart back in action.
link_name: Military Sports Report - After Action – George Lockhart wins first fight since leaving Corps

-- Capt. Brett Friedman

-- Lance Cpl. Kyle Carpenter, grenade blast survivor

status_message: Click the link below to watch video of Lance Cpl. Kyle Carpenter's interview with Marine Corps Times. Carpenter and another Marine, Lance Cpl. Nick Eufrazio, were severely injured during a hand grenade attack in Afghanistan several months ago. The state legislature in Carpenter's native South Carolina has credited him with attempting to shield the blast in an effort to protect his friend. The Corps is investigating the incident, officials say, with hopes of learning whether anyone merits an award.
link_name: Video portrait: Lance Cpl. Kyle Carpenter - Marine Corps Times

status_message: From the story: Lt. Gen. Thomas Waldhauser, head of Marine Corps Forces Central Command, will serve as the consolidated disposition authority as the Corps investigates the Marines depicted online peeing on dead Taliban fighters. He'd likely decide what administrative or disciplinary action they face.

status_message: Navy Secretary Ray Mabus on the Taliban corpse video: "We hold the U.S. Marine Corps to the highest possible standards, and the behavior shown in the video failed to uphold those standards in every possible way. Anyone who is found responsible for these actions will be held appropriately and fully accountable."

BREAKING NEWS: The Marine Corps is promising to investigate a disturbing YouTube video that appears to show a Marine in Afghanistan urinating on the bloody corpse of an alleged Taliban fighter. More to come shortly.

U.S. Marine Lance Cpls. status_message: "Dakota says he'll accept this medal in their name," the president said. "So today, we remember the husband who loved the outdoors — Lt. Michael Johnson. The husband and father they called 'Gunny J' — Gunnery Sgt. Edwin Johnson. The determined Marine who fought to get on that team — Staff Sgt. Aaron Kenefick. The medic who gave his life tending to his teammates — Hospitalman 3rd Class James Layton. And a soldier wounded in that battle who never recovered — Sgt. 1st Class Kenneth Westbrook."

status_message:
"If I'm stiff around Marines, they're going to be stiff, and they're never going to know how to have fun as a Marine. You saw me doing karaoke, but there were no Marines getting up doing karaoke until I got up there, and then all of them got up and they were taking turns singing. I just broke the ice because Marines, they deserve to have fun."

-- SgtMaj Carlton Kent, on his recent karaoke adventures in Europe.

status_message:
"When I graduated from boot camp, it was one of the proudest moments of my life. I loved that I would want into a story and people would ask if I was a Marine. But later, I started to worry when people asked if I was in the Marines or the Army. Finally, when somebody asked if I was in the Air Force, I realized I needed to do something."

-- Gunnery Sgt. Ken Young, on why he took action to improve his physical fitness. He offers up his amazing success story and fitness plan in this week's Marine Corps Times.

status_message: One year ago today, a group of U.S. Marines, soldiers and Afghan security forces were pinned down in a kill zone for hours without an air support or artillery. Three Marines and a corpsman died on the battlefield, and a soldier died Oct. 7, 2009, from wounds sustained in the attack. Rest in peace.

status_message:
You can't instill that Marine attitude too early in life.
Hailey Hinkle, at just seven months, is  showing she has what it takes to serve in the Corps.
"I think I already have a future DI on my hands," said Hailey's mom ,
 Jacqueline Hinkle, who sent Marine Corps Times this photo to cheer up 
the troops.
Hailey's dad, Sgt. Todd Hinkle, is a member of Marine Aviation 
Logistics Squadron 31, based at Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort, S.C.
Tom and Jacqueline have five children, but Hailey is their first daughter.

status_message: Don't worry…this isn't an amphibious exercise gone FUBAR. It's actually an effort by officials in Thailand to recycle old tanks and military vehicles by sinking them into the Gulf of Thailand to become artificial reefs.  The Thai government hopes that the old war machines will the serve as artificial reefs for coral to... help rehabilitate the marine ecology of the region. (Photo by Madaree Tohlala/AFP/Getty Images)

status_message: It's been a tough week for coalition aircraft, with a pair of crashes, including a spectacular one by Canadian Forces pilot Capt. Brian Bews, above,  who was able to eject and parachute to safety just moments before his CF-18 fighter jet crashed and exploded during a practice flight for the  Alberta International Airsh...ow at the Lethbridge County Airport on Friday, July 23, 2010. Bews sustained injuries to his back and knees during the violent ejection, but is expected to make a full recovery (AP Photo/The Canadian Press, Lethbridge Herald, Ian Martens)

status_message:
Every Tuesday throughout the summer, Marine Barracks Washington conducts
 a sunset parade at the Marine Corps War Memorial in 
Arlington, VA. The parade on Tuesday, July 13, 2010 started as normal, 
but drizzle began to fall as members of the Commandant's marched across 
the field playing a medley from the musical "Hair." Umbrellas were 
passed out, and as the musicians sang the chorus from "Let the Sun Shine
 In," the 
skies opened up. The Silent Drill Team managed to make it through 
their portion of the parade, but officials decided to call the event 
shortly after colors passed the reviewing party.(Staffphoto/Sheila)

With an estimated 14,000 images in the collection of the National
Archives, the work of this talented photographic unit is historically
significant not only as a visual record of the war, but also for its
influence on generations of postwar photographers. Faces of War is a
tribute to the vision of Edward Steichen, as well as the men who served
under him, and most importantly to their subjects-the unsung heroes of
the U.S. Navy. Mark Faram is a writer and photographer for the Navy
Times and a veteran of the U.S. Navy.
